article: Family traditions were important in our house, and none was more appreciated than the perfect Christmas tree.  "Dad, can we _ when you trim the tree?" My eldest son, Dan, nine, and his seven-year-old brother John, asked.  "I won't be cutting this year," my husband Bob said. "Dan, you and John are _ enough to measure things. Do it all by yourselves. Think you boys can _ it?" Dan and John were very proud. "We can handle it," Dan _ . "We won't let you down." A few days before Christmas, Dan and John 25 _ in after school. They gathered the _ they'd need and brought them out to the yard, _ the tree waited. I was cooking when I heard the _ sounds as the boys carried the tree into the living room. Then I heard the sound that every mother knows is _ : dead silence. I hurried out to them only to find the tree was cut too _ . John crossed his arms _ across his chest and his eyes filled with tears.  I felt worried. The tree was _ to our holiday. I didn't want the boys to feel _ every time they looked at it. I couldn't lower the ceiling, and I couldn't _ the floor either. Suddenly, a thought came to my mind, which turned the _ into the solution.  "We can't make the tree taller," I said. "But we can put it on a _ position." Dan _ his head. "We could put it on the coffee table. It just might _ ! Let's try it!" When Bob got home and looked at the big tree on top of the coffee table, Dan and John held their _ .  "What a good idea!" he declared. "Why didn't I ever think of such a thing?" John broke into a grin . Dan's chest swelled with pride.
